--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.=
com, "Barry Thomas" <warlord@i...> 
wrote:
>
> G'day Patrik,
> 
> Believe m=
e mate, yours IS a real Nihonto question IMHO.  
The "badge" on the top
> o=
f the handle fitting (kabutogane) is a mon - a family crest, and a 
very ni=
cely
> made one.  These may or may not be real (in the "family" sense) but =

I won't talk
> about that now.  They are fairly often found and usually re=
garded 
as a "good
> sign" of a better class blade in the mounting.  Yours =
is one of the 
so-called
> Genji mon, I believe, a symbol from history - pe=
rhaps someone knows 
more about
> them.  Hawley produced a sheet of all the=
 symbols and I've probably 
still got
> mine around somewhere (40 years of =
detrtitus hanging around my 
neck!!!)
> 
> The writing on the wooden part o=
f the tsuka is I believe the 
signature of the
> man who made the handle.  =
Whilst unusual such signatures are 
sometimes found.
> To me they indicate =
a custom-made tsuka by an artisan and not a 
regular "factory
> job".  Your=
 signature has all the appearances of being "enhanced" 
by someone
> with a=
 felt pen, which is a real pity.  Some of these signatures I 
have found
> =
are of excellent calligraphy.  I believe there were a few families 
of note=
 who
> were handle binders by profession and were involved in creating 
bet=
ter class
> gunto koshirae.  Your tsuka is one of the best-looking and best=
 
condition tsuka
> I have ever seen.  Like new - the silk still has a shee=
n. You are 
fortunate, so
> help to preserve it by only handling the tsuka =
with cotton gloves 
to avoid
> soiling the silk.
> 
> The scratchy signatur=
es on the metal parts are probably those of 
the owner and I
> never pay th=
em any attention as without other documentation it is 
near
> impossible to=
 find who the owner was..
> 
> The wooden blade indicates either (a) that a=
 former owner polished 
the blade and
> put it into shirasaya and had a tsu=
nagi (wooden blade) made for the 
koshirae.  I
> have done this for a Tadah=
iro II katana I had polished.  Or (b) 
that a previous
> owner made his own=
 tsunagi and simply sold off the blade...
> 
> Best regards,
> 
> Barry Tho=
mas
> (Melbourne, Australia)
> 
>

ieces from a guy that bought this at EBAY for a

blade in
> it....=
..he thought that it was a complete sword....but anyway i 
bought it from

 him for a couple of $ now.

and all of the

WHY are they

kosihrae
